pageData.text: The cardiovascular system is necessary to ensure adequate supplies of oxygen and nutrients to the tissues and to remove carbon dioxide and other metabolic waste products. The heart is the main pump of this system. There are several tests of cardiovascular and, especially, cardiac function. In this investigation, students will identify the different components of the <button className='glossary-text'>cardiac cycle</button> and how these components relate to specific ways of observing cardiac function, including <button className='glossary-text'>pulse</button>, blood pressure, and electrical activity.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation – 10 minutes
Activity 1: Pulse Palpation – 30 minutes
Activity 2: Cardiac Output – 5 minutes
Activity 3: Blood Pressure – 20 minutes
Activity 4: Electrocardiogram Interpretation – 20 minutes

pageData.title: Needed but not supplied:
text: Timing device that counts seconds, such as a watch with a second hand or a cell phone with a stopwatch

pageData.text: Note for Instructors: This investigation involves the student providing cardiovascular test results to you as part of the assessment. This is confidential medical information that should not be stored or shared with your health services group or the rest of the class.

Note for Students: The cardiovascular tests performed in this investigation are for educational purposes and should not be used for diagnosis of medical conditions. If your results seem unusual, seek advice from a medical professional.

text: Recall the main structures of the heart, including the chambers, valves, attached large vessels, and components of the .
Identify the events shown on a normal <button className='glossary-text'>electrocardiogram</button>, and analyze traces.
Identify the events of the <button className='glossary-text'>cardiac cycle</button>, and relate them to <button className='glossary-text'>heart sounds</button> and electrical activity.
Determine <button className='glossary-text'>heart rate</button> through <button className='glossary-text'>pulse</button> measurements and electrocardiogram interpretation.
Describe the basis for blood pressure.

Calculate <button className='glossary-text'>pulse pressure</button>, <button className='glossary-text'>mean arterial pressure</button>, and <button className='glossary-text'>cardiac output</button>, and compare the sample results to standard values.

pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.subTitle: Protocol symbols

pageData.subTitle: Hazard pictograms
pageData.altText: warning symbol, corrosion symbol, flammable symbol, toxic symbol, environment symbol, health hazard symbol

pageData.text: Heart disease is a term used to describe a wide range of conditions. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports that in the United States one person dies every thirty-six seconds from cardiovascular disease<sup class='bodySupscript'>1</sup>. Coronary artery disease, caused by a build-up of plaque in the arteries, is the most common heart disease in the United States, with an estimated 7% of the adult population (over the age of 20) affected. This image shows a cross section of an artery filled with plaque. Other conditions include heart arrhythmia, congenital heart defects, heart valve disease, disease of the heart muscle, and heart infection.

The good news is that by replacing unhealthy lifestyle choices with healthy ones, you can reduce your risk of developing heart disease. Smoking increases the risk of developing heart disease: nicotine tightens blood vessels and carbon monoxide can damage their inner lining. Heart attacks are more common in smokers than in nonsmokers. A diet that is high in fat, salt, sugar, and cholesterol can contribute to obesity and the development of heart disease. Stress, lack of regular exercise, and poor oral hygiene have also been linked to developing heart disease. It is recommended everyone get at least thirty minutes of exercise regularly and eat a balanced diet.
1Heart Disease Facts. (2022). Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). https://www.cdc.gov/heartdisease/facts.htm

pageData.desc: A micrograph cross section of a human artery that is filled with plaque build-up.
pageData.altText: A micrograph cross section of a human artery that is filled with plaque build-up.

pageData.text: The cardiovascular system circulates blood through the body. The heart pumps blood through blood vessels—arteries, capillaries, and veins. As blood flows through these vessels, it  dioxide and waste products from them.

pageData.altText: Human Body: Cardiovascular System

pageData.subTitle: The human heart
pageData.text: The human heart is a muscular pump about the size of a human fist. It has 4 chambers—2 and 2 . It has 4 heart valves. Two are located between the chambers and 2 exit the heart, preventing the backflow of blood.

pageData.altText: cardiac muscle

pageData.text: The heart consists of cardiac muscle, a striated and involuntary muscle. Individual cardiac muscle cells (cardiomyocytes) are connected by intercalated discs that coordinate synchronized muscle contraction.

pageData.subTitle: The 2 circulation loops
pageData.text:
Pulmonary
The right side of the heart pumps oxygen-deficient blood to the lungs where it releases CO2 and becomes oxygenated. This blood then returns to the heart.
Pathway: right atrium → right ventricle → lungs → left atrium

Systemic
The left side of the heart pumps oxygenated blood to body tissues where it delivers O2 and picks up CO2 and other waste products. This deoxygenated blood then travels back to the heart where it begins the pulmonary loop.
Pathway: left atrium → left ventricle → body → right atrium

pageData.subTitle: Blood composition
pageData.text: The human body contains about 5 liters of blood. Blood consists of red blood cells, white blood cells, platelets, and plasma.

Arteries carry oxygenated blood away from the heart to arterioles and then to capillaries. Capillary walls are thin—only a single cell thick—allowing O<sub>2</sub> and nutrients to enter tissues while waste products are removed. Blood then travels through venules and into larger veins that carry it back to the heart.

The heart provides the main pumping force needed to move blood through the cardiovascular system. The muscular walls of the heart are known as the . As shown in Figure 1, the heart has four chambers. The upper two are the , and the lower two are the . The thin-walled atria are sometimes referred to as receiving chambers because they receive blood as it enters the heart. The ventricles, with their thicker myocardial walls, are also known as pumping chambers, because they forcefully eject blood from the heart. One-way valves are located between the atria and ventricles and then between the ventricles and large vessels through which blood leaves the heart. These valves ensure that blood flows in the correct direction.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Diagram of blood flow through the chambers of the heart and its large vessels

pageData.subTitle: Blood Flow and Heart Sounds
pageData.text: Blood follows a fixed pathway through the heart and its large vessels (see ). Oxygen-depleted blood from the body enters the right atrium of the heart through the superior and inferior . Contraction of the right atrium sends the blood a short distance through the into the right ventricle. When the right ventricle contracts, blood passes through the and into the pulmonary trunk. This large vessel splits into the right and left pulmonary arteries, which convey blood to the lungs. Oxygenated blood from the lungs returns to the left atrium of the heart via pulmonary veins. Contraction of the left atrium sends the blood through the (or mitral valve) into the left ventricle. This is the heart chamber with the thickest . When the left ventricle contracts, blood passes through the into the aorta. The aorta is the largest artery of the body and receives blood under high pressure from the powerful contractions of the left ventricle. Arteries arising from the aorta convey blood to capillary beds throughout the body.

are produced by the closing of heart valves, which results in a temporary disturbance in blood flow. The two most noticeable heart sounds are often described as lub-dup (or lub-dub). Each lub-dup represents a single heartbeat. The first sound, lub, is caused by the closing of the tricuspid and bicuspid valves as the start to contract. It is a relatively long, deep sound. The second sound, dup, is caused by the closing of the aortic and pulmonary valves when the ventricles stop contracting and start to relax. It is a shorter and sharper sound. These and other heart sounds can be detected by examination with a stethoscope, a procedure known as . When the is determined by counting heartbeats, this rate is called the .

pageData.question: The “lub” sound of a heartbeat is the sound of what heart valves closing?

options.text: all four valves of the heart

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: To emphasize the bicuspid valve, place the chest piece over the apex (tip) of the heart, in the fifth intercostal space, toward the center of the clavicle (collarbone).

pageData.question: During each heartbeat, the tricuspid and bicuspid heart valves close as the ventricles start to contract. This can be heard as a deep “lub” sound using a stethoscope. What is the purpose of these two valves closing during a heartbeat?

options.text: to prevent blood from flowing backward into the atria
to prevent blood from flowing forward into arteries
to ensure one-way blood flow into veins
to ensure one-way blood flow into the atria
to stimulate the contraction of the atria

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The tricuspid and bicuspid valves separate the atria from the ventricles. When they close, they prevent the backward flow of blood as the ventricles contract.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Heart sounds are produced by the closing of heart valves, which results in a temporary disturbance in blood flow. The two most noticeable heart sounds are often described as lub-dup (or lub-dub). Each lub-dup represents a single heartbeat. The first sound, lub, is caused by the closing of the tricuspid and bicuspid valves as the ventricles start to contract. It is a relatively long, deep sound. The second sound, dup, is caused by the closing of the aortic and pulmonary valves when the ventricles stop contracting and start to relax. It is a shorter and sharper sound. These and other heart sounds can be detected by examination with a stethoscope, a procedure known as auscultation.

img.alt: Figure 1: Diagram of blood flow through the chambers of the heart and its large vessels

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Heart sounds are produced by the closing of heart valves, which results in a temporary disturbance in blood flow. The two most noticeable heart sounds are often described as lub-dup (or lub-dub). Each lub-dup represents a single heartbeat. The first sound, lub, is caused by the closing of the tricuspid and bicuspid valves as the ventricles start to contract. It is a relatively long, deep sound. The second sound, dup, is caused by the closing of the aortic and pulmonary valves when the ventricles stop contracting and start to relax. It is a shorter and sharper sound. These and other heart sounds can be detected by examination with a stethoscope, a procedure known as auscultation.

img.alt: Figure 1: Diagram of blood flow through the chambers of the heart and its large vessels

pageData.subTitle: The Cardiac Conduction System
pageData.text: Most myocardial cells are specialized for contraction. However, a small subset of specialized conductive cells forms a network that coordinates the activities of the contractile cells. This network is the (see Figure 2). Cells of the cardiac conduction system are electrically excitable, having a charge difference across the plasma membrane that is easily changed. At rest, the electrical potential is negative on the inside of the membrane. When this charge difference is lost and the inner membrane charge shifts toward positive, the cell is said to be . Restoration of the charge difference is . There are two clusters, or nodes, of cells with highly unstable resting potentials that undergo cyclical depolarization and repolarization. Their role is to set the pace of heart contractions, or .

pageData.altText: Figure 2: Diagram of the cardiac conduction system

pageData.text:
• The first of these nodes is the , located in the superior and posterior region of the right atrium (see ). It is commonly called the pacemaker of the heart because it generates the electrical signal for contraction and sets the basic . The SA node typically initiates between 60 and 100 signals per minute, setting the heart rate at 60 to 100 beats per minute (bpm).
  • The signal from the SA node travels through the walls of the to the , located in the inferior area of the right atrium between the atrium and the right ventricle. The AV node imposes a slight delay (approximately 0.1 second) on the SA signal. This provides enough time for the atria to complete their contraction before the start to contract.
  • When the AV node discharges, the signal passes along the , which divides into left and right . The bundle branches travel through the interventricular septum (the that separates the ventricles) to the apex tip of the heart.
  • At the apex, the bundle branches transmit the signal to , which relay the signal throughout the walls of the ventricles.

pageData.question: Which statement is true about the sinoatrial (SA) node and atrioventricular (AV) node?

options.text: They set the pace of heart contractions.
They can be heard on the right side of the chest over the apex of the heart.
“Lup” is caused by the repolarization of the AV node.
“Dub” is caused by the depolarization of the SA node.
Arteries arising from the nodes convey oxygen-poor blood throughout the body.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: They set the pace of heart contractions, or heart rate (HR).

pageData.question: What is the relationship between the sinoatrial (SA) node and the atrioventricular (AV) node?

options.text: The signal from the SA node travels to the AV node.
The signal from the AV node travels to the SA node after a slight delay.
The signals from the SA and AV nodes are generated simultaneously.
The signals from one node do not affect the other node.
The signal from one node travels to the other node and back again in a cycle.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The signal from the SA node travels through the walls of the atria to the atrioventricular (AV) node.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The role of the two heart nodes is to set the pace of heart contractions, or heart rate (HR). The sinoatrial (SA) node is commonly called the pacemaker of the heart because it generates the electrical signal for contraction and sets the basic heart rate. The SA node typically initiates between 60 and 100 signals per minute, setting the heart rate at 60 to 100 beats per minute (bpm). The signal from the SA node travels through the walls of the atria to the atrioventricular (AV) node, located in the inferior area of the right atrium, just above the right ventricle. The AV node imposes a slight delay (approximately 0.1 second) on the SA signal.

img.alt: Figure 3: Typical placement of electrocardiograph chest leads, showing V1 and V2 on each side of the sternum and V3 through V6 distributed away from the midline toward the armpit

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The role of the two heart nodes is to set the pace of heart contractions, or heart rate (HR). The sinoatrial (SA) node is commonly called the pacemaker of the heart because it generates the electrical signal for contraction and sets the basic heart rate. The SA node typically initiates between 60 and 100 signals per minute, setting the heart rate at 60 to 100 beats per minute (bpm). The signal from the SA node travels through the walls of the atria to the atrioventricular (AV) node, located in the inferior area of the right atrium, just above the right ventricle. The AV node imposes a slight delay (approximately 0.1 second) on the SA signal.

img.alt: Figure 3: Typical placement of electrocardiograph chest leads, showing V1 and V2 on each side of the sternum and V3 through V6 distributed away from the midline toward the armpit

pageData.text: The electrical activities of the can be examined using an electrocardiograph machine. Leads from the electrocardiograph must be carefully attached on the surface of the subject’s chest according to several anatomical landmarks. A standard arrangement of chest leads, labeled V1–V6, is shown in Figure 3. There are also limb leads on the wrists and ankles. The electrocardiograph generates a graph of the heart’s electrical activity, called an , or ECG (also abbreviated EKG).

pageData.altText: Figure 3: Typical placement of electrocardiograph chest leads, showing V1 and V2 on each side of the sternum and V3 through V6 distributed away from the midline toward the armpit

pageData.text: The normal <button className='glossary-text'>ECG</button> in Figure 4 represents a typical pattern of electrical activity. The main features are designated P, Q, R, S, and T.

• The corresponds to depolarization of the , which triggers their contraction. The small size of the P wave reflects the small size and thin of the atria and the relatively weak stimulus needed to initiate their contraction.
  • The indicates depolarization of the . The large size of the QRS complex reflects the robust stimulus needed to initiate contraction of the large ventricles with their thick myocardium.
  • The represents depolarization of the interventricular septum, where the are located. This is a very brief event, not always represented in an ECG.
  • The is the largest wave of an ECG and depicts depolarization of the ventricles.
  • The is generated by depolarization of the , occurring late in ventricular depolarization.
  • The indicates the of the ventricles.

pageData.altText: Figure 4: Simplified ECG traces from a normal subject and an individual with ST elevation myocardial infarction; waves, segments, and intervals are labeled.

pageData.text: The <button className='glossary-text'>atria</button> also undergo <button className='glossary-text'>repolarization</button>, but the event is small and not typically seen in an <button className='glossary-text'>ECG</button> because it coincides with the massive <button className='glossary-text'>QRS complex</button>. The changing upward and downward deflections of the ECG waves are due to the changing direction of the depolarization as it passes through the conduction system.
Interpretation of an ECG also involves the segments and intervals between waves, as seen in the normal ECG in .

• The is the time from the onset of the to the onset of the , from the arrival of the depolarization signal at the atria to its arrival at the .
  • The starts at the end of the P wave and ends at the beginning of the Q wave. It represents the time during which atrial depolarization is complete and the AV node is slightly delaying transmission of the signal to the ventricles.
  • The is the time from the end of the QRS complex to the start of the , during which the ventricles are completely .

• The is the time from the start of the Q wave to the end of the T wave, from the arrival of ventricular depolarization to repolarization of the ventricles.
An ECG can be used to determine the by measuring the time elapsed between repetitions of a given wave. In this context, the heart rate is called the . Because it is so prominent and appears so consistently on a normal ECG, the QRS complex, particularly the , is usually selected for this purpose. The RR interval is the time between the peaks of R waves. For a normal adult heart rate of 60–100 bpm, the RR interval will be 0.6–1 second.

pageData.question: Which two elements of an ECG trace best represent atrial and ventricular contraction, respectively?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The P wave and R wave correspond to depolarization of the atria and ventricles, respectively. Depolarization of these heart chambers triggers their contraction during each heartbeat.

pageData.question: The P wave, which triggers atrial contraction, is small compared to the R wave, which triggers ventricular contraction. Which of the following best describes the significance of the size difference between these two waves?

options.text: A weak stimulus is required to contract the atria compared to the ventricles.
The atria contract for a shorter amount of time compared to the ventricles.
A strong stimulus is required to contract the atria compared to the ventricles.
The atria contract for a longer amount of time compared to the ventricles.
The atria are less important in the completion of a heartbeat than the ventricles.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The height of a wave on an ECG corresponds to the amount of electrical stimulus flowing through the heart at that point in time. The P wave’s small size signifies that the atria need only a weak stimulus to contract. By comparison, R waves are the largest wave in an ECG trace and signify that the ventricles need a strong stimulus to contract.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: A graph of the heart’s electrical activity is called an electrocardiogram (ECG).  The larger the wave, the greater the electrical stimulus generated by the heart. A heartbeat starts with the P wave, which corresponds to depolarization of the atria thus triggering their contraction. The Q wave represents the depolarization of the interventricular septum, where the bundle branches are located. This is a very brief event not always represented in an ECG. The R wave is the largest wave of an ECG and depicts the initial depolarization of the ventricles. The S wave is generated by depolarization of the Purkinje fibers, occurring late in ventricular depolarization. The Q, R, and S waves together are also known as the QRS complex, which indicates depolarization, and subsequently contraction, of the ventricles. The T wave indicates the repolarization of the ventricles.

img.alt: Simplified ECG traces from a normal subject and an individual with ST elevation myocardial infarction; waves, segments, and intervals are labeled.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: A graph of the heart’s electrical activity is called an electrocardiogram (ECG).  The larger the wave, the greater the electrical stimulus generated by the heart. A heartbeat starts with the P wave, which corresponds to depolarization of the atria thus triggering their contraction. The Q wave represents the depolarization of the interventricular septum, where the bundle branches are located. This is a very brief event not always represented in an ECG. The R wave is the largest wave of an ECG and depicts the initial depolarization of the ventricles. The S wave is generated by depolarization of the Purkinje fibers, occurring late in ventricular depolarization. The Q, R, and S waves together are also known as the QRS complex, which indicates depolarization, and subsequently contraction, of the ventricles. The T wave indicates the repolarization of the ventricles.

img.alt: Simplified ECG traces from a normal subject and an individual with ST elevation myocardial infarction; waves, segments, and intervals are labeled.

pageData.subTitle: The Cardiac Cycle
pageData.text: Thanks to the , the contractions and relaxations of the heart chambers occur in a synchronized series of events called the . Relaxation is referred to as , and contraction is . Because the cardiac cycle repeats, description of its events can start at any point. The cardiac cycle follows the electrical activity of the heart, so it is useful to consider these events together, as in Figure 5.

• Just after the , the are in diastole, receiving blood, and the are just entering diastole. Pressure in the ventricles falls. The bicuspid and are open, so blood flows into the ventricles. The aortic and close, producing the dup sound. This valve closure marks the onset of , in which the ventricular walls become progressively more relaxed and blood flows in from the atria.
  • Atrial systole is initiated by the . The pressure exerted by the contracting atrial walls forces the remaining blood into the ventricles, which are at the end of diastole. The ventricles reach their maximum blood volume.
  • The marks the depolarization of the ventricles. As they enter systole, the atria relax. The bicuspid and tricuspid valves close, producing the lub sound. The closure of the bicuspid and tricuspid valves marks the end of isovolumetric relaxation. There is a brief time when all four heart valves are closed and the volume of blood in the ventricles remains steady, called . As pressure builds in the ventricles, they eject blood through the aortic and pulmonary valves; this is the end of isovolumetric contraction.

pageData.altText: Figure 5: Diagram of the cardiac cycle accompanied by an ECG trace

pageData.text: An provides an informative assessment of heart function. For example, a , commonly called a heart attack, occurs when blood flow to part of the heart is interrupted. The affected dies and is incapable of expected electrical activity. If a patient is suspected of having had an MI, an ECG is useful in determining the type. For example, an ECG indicative of ST elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) is shown next to a normal trace in . The is abnormally elevated over baseline. Recall that the ST segment is associated with ventricular depolarization; therefore, ST elevation suggests damage to ventricular myocardium. However, an ECG alone is not enough to decide that an MI has occurred or determine its type; additional tests are needed to confirm the diagnosis. An ECG is also used in diagnosing many other heart disorders.

pageData.subTitle: Blood Pressure and Pulse
pageData.text: Another way to assess cardiovascular function is by measuring the waves of pressure from blood that has been ejected from the left . This pressure is transmitted through the arteries as they branch from the aorta. The pressure drops with increasing distance from the aorta as the blood flows through ever-smaller arteries; arterioles; capillaries; venules; veins; and, eventually, the superior and inferior (see Figure 6).

pageData.altText: Figure 6: Graph of blood pressure versus blood vessel type, showing the overall decline in pressure between the aorta and venae cavae, and the distinction between systolic and diastolic pressure in the arteries

pageData.text: The pressure waves in certain arteries close to the body’s surface can be detected via (feeling with the fingertips). Pressure waves detected in this way are known as the , which is synonymous with (that is, the rate of the ). The best locations for pulse palpation have firm underlying tissue, such as bone and cartilage, against which the artery can be pressed. Figure 7 depicts the most common along with their respective arteries. The figure also shows the , which is detected by at the apex of the heart. In Figure 8, an individual is shown palpating her radial pulse. Once detected, the pulse is counted for one minute. Alternatively, the pulse can be counted for 15 seconds and then multiplied by four.

pageData.altText: Figure 8: Wrist and hands of an individual taking her own radial pulse by palpation
Figure 7: Drawing of the common pulse points of the adult body

pageData.text: Typical resting <button className='glossary-text'>pulse</button> rates for adults are between 60–100 bpm. A slow pulse is called <button className='glossary-text'>bradycardia</button>. Resting pulses of 40–60 bpm often occur in athletes who are in peak condition. However, in other circumstances, bradycardia may arise from dysfunction of the conduction system, especially the SA node. <button className='glossary-text'>Tachycardia</button> is a pulse over 100 bpm. Elevated pulse occurs normally with exercise but is reason for concern if sustained at rest. Tachycardia can stem from a disordered conduction system, as in atrial tachycardia. This condition is caused by the presence of an extra atrial pacemaker node, which sets the <button className='glossary-text'>heart rate</button> instead of the SA node. Untreated atrial tachycardia can lead to atrial fibrillation, a type of arrhythmia (irregular heartbeat) in which atrial contractions are rapid and irregular. Tachycardia can also be caused by certain drugs, including caffeine and nicotine, as well as pain and anxiety.

Arterial blood pressure has two components: and (). Systolic pressure is produced by ventricular contraction and is the higher of the two (the pressure caused by the heart contracting and pushing out blood, the top number on a blood pressure reading). Diastolic pressure is exerted during ventricular . Large arteries like the aorta have elastic walls that expand with each wave of pressure generated by ventricular . During ventricular diastole, elastic recoil of the large arteries is sufficient to propel the blood until the next ventricular systole. When arterial blood pressure is measured using a device called a , or blood pressure cuff, the readings are given as the systolic pressure over the diastolic pressure. For example, if a person has a systolic pressure of 120 millimeters of mercury (mm Hg) and a diastolic pressure of 80 mm Hg, then the blood pressure is 120/80.

For an adult, a blood pressure of less than 120/80 is considered normal and a pressure of 140/90 or greater is high, a condition known as . Intermediate readings are classified as , meaning the individual is at high risk of developing hypertension. Hypertension can damage the cardiovascular system and the organs it serves, including the kidneys, eyes, and brain. Risk factors for hypertension include body weight, age, race, family history, physical activity, tobacco use, sodium intake, and alcohol consumption. It is also possible to have , which occurs when blood pressure is 90/60 or lower. Hypotension can have a variety of causes, including dehydration and blood loss.There are related pressures that can be calculated from systolic and . The is the difference between and diastolic pressure. An individual with a blood pressure of 120/80 would have a PP of 40 mm Hg. is the pressure that forces arterial blood to the capillary beds. MAP is calculated using the following formula:MAP = diastolic pressure + PP /3

For example, someone with a blood pressure of 120/80 would have a MAP of 93 mm Hg:MAP = 80 mm Hg + 40 mm Hg /3 = 93 mm HgAdditional measurements of heart function include and . Stroke volume is the volume of blood ejected from a single ventricle, typically the left ventricle, with each contraction. Cardiac output is the product of stroke volume and in bpm.CO = SV x HRFor example, if an individual has a stroke volume of 70 milliliters (mL) and a heart rate of 70 bpm, the CO will be 4.9 liters per minute (L/min).CO = 70 mL x 70 bpm = 4,900 mL/minute = 4.9 L/minA typical, healthy adult has a minimum CO of 4.7 L/min, so 4.9 L/min would be considered a healthy CO.In the following activities, you will palpate for the pulse, calculate cardiac output, calculate and interpret blood pressures, and interpret ECG traces.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes diastolic pressure?

options.text: the pressure in the arteries as the ventricles relax
the pressure in the arteries as the ventricles contract
the pressure in the veins as blood returns to the heart
the pressure in the ventricles during pulmonary circulation
the pressure in the atria during systemic circulation

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Diastolic pressure is exerted during ventricular diastole, or ventricular relaxation, as large arteries maintain the pressure generated by ventricular systole, or ventricular contraction.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes the source of diastolic pressure?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The pressure from ventricular systole is maintained during ventricular diastole as large elastic arteries constrict back to their original size following ventricular systole. The term “diastolic” in “diastolic pressure” refers to when the pressure is measured rather than the source of the pressure.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Arterial blood pressure has two components: systolic pressure and diastolic pressure. Systolic pressure is produced by ventricular systole, or ventricular contraction, and is the higher of the two. Diastolic pressure is exerted during ventricular diastole, or ventricular relaxation. During ventricular systole, large arteries like the aorta dilate (expand) with each wave of pressure generated by the ventricles; this is because these arteries have elastic walls. During ventricular diastole, the elastic artery walls constrict (tighten) back to their original diameter; this recoil is sufficient to propel the blood until the next ventricular systole. When arterial blood pressure is measured using a device called a sphygmomanometer, or blood pressure cuff, the readings are given as the systolic pressure over the diastolic pressure. For example, if a person has a systolic pressure of 120 millimeters of mercury (mm Hg) and a diastolic pressure of 80 mm Hg, then the blood pressure is 120/80.

img.alt: Figure 6: Graph of blood pressure versus blood vessel type, showing the overall decline in pressure between the aorta and venae cavae, and the distinction between systolic and diastolic pressure in the arteries

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Arterial blood pressure has two components: systolic pressure and diastolic pressure. Systolic pressure is produced by ventricular systole, or ventricular contraction, and is the higher of the two. Diastolic pressure is exerted during ventricular diastole, or ventricular relaxation. During ventricular systole, large arteries like the aorta dilate (expand) with each wave of pressure generated by the ventricles; this is because these arteries have elastic walls. During ventricular diastole, the elastic artery walls constrict (tighten) back to their original diameter; this recoil is sufficient to propel the blood until the next ventricular systole. When arterial blood pressure is measured using a device called a sphygmomanometer, or blood pressure cuff, the readings are given as the systolic pressure over the diastolic pressure. For example, if a person has a systolic pressure of 120 millimeters of mercury (mm Hg) and a diastolic pressure of 80 mm Hg, then the blood pressure is 120/80.

img.alt: Figure 6: Graph of blood pressure versus blood vessel type, showing the overall decline in pressure between the aorta and venae cavae, and the distinction between systolic and diastolic pressure in the arteries

pageData.desc: This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. In Activity 1, you will locate and describe five pulse points. You will then measure the radial pulse of a seated subject. Next, you will choose a second pulse point and measure this pulse of the seated subject. You will then measure the same pulse points of a standing subject and then a supine subject. In Activity 2, you will estimate the subject’s cardiac output for each position in Activity 1.  In Activity 3, you will calculate the pulse pressure and mean arterial pressure for five sets of patient blood pressure data. Then, you will evaluate the status of each patient. In Activity 4, you will identify the parts of an ECG trace. Then, you will determine the RR interval of the trace, calculate the RR interval duration, and calculate the heart rate.
pageData.altText: This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. In Activity 1, you will locate and describe five pulse points. You will then measure the radial pulse of a seated subject. Next, you will choose a second pulse point and measure this pulse of the seated subject. You will then measure the same pulse points of a standing subject and then a supine subject. In Activity 2, you will estimate the subject’s cardiac output for each position in Activity 1.  In Activity 3, you will calculate the pulse pressure and mean arterial pressure for five sets of patient blood pressure data. Then, you will evaluate the status of each patient. In Activity 4, you will identify the parts of an ECG trace. Then, you will determine the RR interval of the trace, calculate the RR interval duration, and calculate the heart rate.

pageData.subTitle: Needed but not supplied:
pageData.text:
• Calculator
  • Timing device that counts seconds, such as a watch with a second hand or a cell phone with a stopwatch
Read all instructions for the laboratory activities before beginning, and follow the instructions closely.
Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing each activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing each activity.
This investigation requires that you or a partner participate in short periods of mild physical activity. If you are unable to perform these activities, please alert the course instructor.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which is the first heart chamber to receive blood at the start of a cardiac cycle?
The heart sounds are commonly described as “lub dup”. Which of the following best describes the causes of these sounds?

options.text: the atrioventricular valves closing; the pulmonary and aortic valves closing
the bicuspid valve closing; the tricuspid valve closing
the tricuspid and pulmonary valves opening; the bicuspid and aortic valves closing
the atrioventricular valves opening; blood entering the ventricles
the bicuspid valve opening; the tricuspid valve closing

assestmentData.question: During which of the following events is blood leaving the heart at its lowest pressure?
Where is blood pressure typically measured?
Contractions of the heart are caused by electrical impulses generated at which of the following structures?
Which part of an ECG trace represents the “resetting” of the electrical system of the heart?

A nurse takes the pulse of a patient in the emergency room and determines that the patient is experiencing tachycardia. Which of the following best describes the patient’s pulse in beats per minute (bpm)?

options.text: The pulse is between 60 and 100 bpm.
The pulse is between 40 and 60 bpm.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following blood pressure readings represents prehypertension?
Which of the following activities is NOT included in this laboratory investigation?
Which of the following describes the artery most often used to take a person’s pulse and the site of this pulse point on the body?

options.text: radial artery; inside of the wrist
temporal artery; side of the head
popliteal artery; back of the knee

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read the instructions before you begin working.
View the Cardiovascular Physiology video for instructions on .

You may want to have your computer or mobile device nearby during the investigation to replay the video for reference. (This video also includes instructions on how to use a blood pressure cuff and stethoscope, which may be of interest, although these are not activities you will carry out for this investigation.)

Clear a work area with comfortable seating so you or your partner can sit with the back supported and both feet flat on the floor. For Activity 1D, you will need to have a location where you or your partner can lie down comfortably, such as a bed or sofa.
Obtain all materials.

You will begin Activity 1 by locating five common <button className='glossary-text'>pulse points</button> on the subject (either you or a test subject). You will then measure the subject’s <button className='glossary-text'>pulse</button> while they are seated, standing, and supine - both at the radial pulse and at a pulse of your choice.

pages.title: Locating the Pulse Points (2 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
  Locating the Pulse Points (2 steps)

typeBefore.text: There are several common (). In this activity, you will locate the at the five points listed in Table 1. These points are also demonstrated in the Cardiovascular Physiology video viewed during preparation.

pageData.text: To palpate the pulse, press the index and middle fingers against the pulse point as shown in . Press gently, just until you feel the pulse. (You may need to slowly feel around the area to locate the pulse.) Then reduce the pressure so you can still feel the pulse but are not restricting blood flow.
Enter your observations in Data Table 1, noting which pulses you were or were not able to successfully palpate. Include notes, such as the relative strength or ease of location for each pulse.

tableData.text: Side (temple) of the head on the temporal bone, just in front of the ear
Press very gently. The bone is thin here.
Side of the neck, just behind and to the side of the larynx (voice box, or Adam’s apple)
This pulse tends to be strong due to the proximity of the carotid artery to the aorta.
Inner crease of the wrist, on the same side as the base of the thumb
Due to its ease of accessibility, this is the most commonly used pulse point.
Center of the inner crease of the elbow, slightly toward the body
This is the pulse point most commonly used when measuring blood pressure.
Center of the back of the knee
This pulse point is commonly used for infants.

typeBefore.title:
B
 Measuring the Pulse in a Sitting Position (5 steps)

pageData.text: Sit comfortably, with your back supported and feet flat on the floor, and relax for at least 2 minutes. (If you have a partner, have your partner sit instead.)
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Locate the radial pulse.
Set your timing device for 1 minute, and count the heartbeats. Remain seated (or have your partner remain seated) as you record your count in Data Table 2.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Repeat the radial pulse count with the timer set to 15 seconds. Record your count in Data Table 2, and multiply the result by 4.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Repeat this procedure for another pulse point of your choice. This should be a pulse point you can easily reach while you (or your partner) are sitting, standing, or supine (lying on the back, faceup). Remember to remain seated between each count. Record your results in Data Table 2.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

typeBefore.title:
C
 Measuring the Pulse in a Standing Position (2 steps)

pageData.text: Stand in place during this part of the activity. If you have a partner, ask your partner to stand. Wait for at least 2 minutes before proceeding.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Take the radial pulse and the pulse at the same point you chose in Activity 1B. For each pulse, count the heartbeats for 1 minute. Remain standing in place (or have your partner stand in place) between each count. Record your counts in Data Table 3.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

typeBefore.title:
D
 Measuring the Pulse in a Supine Position (2 steps)

pageData.text: Lie on your back (faceup) during this part of the activity. If you have a partner, ask your partner to lie down. Wait at least 2 minutes before proceeding.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Take the radial pulse and the pulse at the same point you chose in Activity 1B. Count the heartbeats for 1 minute, remaining supine between each count. Record your counts in Data Table 4.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: In Activity 2, you will use the data from Activity 1 to estimate the <button className='glossary-text'>cardiac output (CO)</button> of the subject in each body position.
Write the 1-minute radial values from standing, sitting, and supine positions recorded in Activity 1 in Data Table 5.
Use the counts to estimate the for each position. Assume a of 70 mL per heartbeat. Use this formula: CO = SV x HRSV is the stroke volume, and HR is the .

In Activity 3, you will evaluate each pair of systolic and diastolic blood pressures and determine if the values are normal or if they indicate a heart condition. You will also calculate the <button className='glossary-text'>pulse pressure (PP)</button> and <button className='glossary-text'>mean arterial pressure (MAP)</button> for each blood pressure reading.

Evaluate each pair of systolic and diastolic blood pressures given in Data Table 6, and determine if the values are normal or if they indicate , , or . Calculate the and using the following formulas:PP = systolic pressure – diastolic pressureMAP = diastolic pressure + PP /3

In Activity 4, you will observe an ECG trace and identify its parts. You will then interpret the trace to determine the RR interval, the RR interval duration, and <button className='glossary-text'>heart rate</button>.
Identify the following parts of the ECG trace in Figure 9: , , , , , , , , , and . Refer to the normal ECG in .

pageData.altText: Figure 9: Normal ECG trace on ECG grid paper

pageData.text: Recall that the RR interval is the time between the peaks of R waves. To determine the RR interval, count the small squares between the peaks of two consecutive R waves. Start with the R wave on the left side of the trace. Count the squares to the peak of the next R wave, and record this number in Data Table 7 as the RR interval.

The horizontal axis on an ECG grid represents time, and the vertical axis represents voltage. Each small square represents 0.04 seconds, and each large square represents 0.2 seconds. A large square represents 0.5 millivolts (mV); however, since you are using the ECG trace to determine , you are only concerned with time. Multiply the number of small squares you counted for each RR interval by 0.04 to obtain the RR interval duration in seconds. Record this information in Data Table 7.Convert the RR interval to heartbeats per minute by dividing 60 by the RR interval duration.heart rate = 60/RR interval durationEnter the heart rate in Data Table 7.
There is no disposal or cleanup necessary for this investigation.
You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.
pageData.confirmationMessage: Are you sure you want to submit your work? You will not be able to edit the lab notebook after submitting your work.

pageData.altText: completion

text: Which arterial pulse was easiest to feel? Explain your answer.

pageData.title: Data Table 2. Measuring Pulse in a Sitting Position

text: Would it be more accurate to measure the pulse for 15 seconds or for a full minute? Explain your answer.

pageData.title: Data Table 3. Measuring Pulse in a Standing Position
Data Table 4. Measuring Pulse in a Supine Position

text: Compare your results for the different positions listed in Data Table 5. Were the number of heart beats per minute approximately the same for each position? Why or why not?
Based on the results reported in Data Table 7, does the person have a heart rate in the normal range for an adult at rest? If not, in what way does it vary from normal?

This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. In Activity 1, you will locate and describe five pulse points. You will then measure the radial pulse of a seated subject. Next, you will choose a second pulse point and measure this pulse of the seated subject. You will then measure the same pulse points of a standing subject and then a supine subject. In Activity 2, you will estimate the subject’s cardiac output for each position in Activity 1.  In Activity 3, you will calculate the pulse pressure and mean arterial pressure for five sets of patient blood pressure data. Then, you will evaluate the status of each patient. In Activity 4, you will identify the parts of an ECG trace. Then, you will determine the RR interval of the trace, calculate the RR interval duration, and calculate the heart rate.

tableData.text: Side (temple) of the head on the temporal bone, just in front of the ear
Press very gently. The bone is thin here.
Side of the neck, just behind and to the side of the larynx (voice box, or Adam’s apple)
This pulse tends to be strong due to the proximity of the carotid artery to the aorta.
Inner crease of the wrist, on the same side as the base of the thumb
Due to its ease of accessibility, this is the most commonly used pulse point.
Center of the inner crease of the elbow, slightly toward the body
This is the pulse point most commonly used when measuring blood pressure.
Center of the back of the knee
This pulse point is commonly used for infants.

data.title: Aortic valve
data.content: Allows for blood from the left ventricle to be pumped up  into the aorta

data.title: Apical pulse
data.content: An arterial pulse site that can be felt on the left side of the chest over the pointed end, or apex, of the hear

data.title: Atria
data.content: The upper two chambers of the heart, “receiving chambers”, receive blood as it enters the heart

data.title: Atrioventricular (AV) node
data.content: Located in the inferior area of the right atrium, just above the right ventricle, the AV node imposes a slight delay (approximately 0.1 second) on the SA signal

data.title: Auscultation
data.content: Examination with a stethoscope

data.title: Bicuspid valve (mitral valve)
data.content: A valve that only allows blood to flow from the left atrium to the left ventricle

data.title: Bradycardia
data.content: Slow pulse

data.title: Bundle branches
data.content: Allows for the passage of electrical impulses through the heart

data.title: Bundle of His
data.content: Cells that carry electrical signals from the AV node to the bundle branches

data.title: Cardiac conduction system
data.content: A small subset of specialized conductive cells forms a network that coordinates the activities of the contractile cells

data.title: Cardiac cycle
data.content: Contractions and relaxations of the heart chambers occur in a synchronized series of events

data.title: Cardiac output (CO)
data.content: The product of stroke volume and heart rate in bpm.

data.title: Depolarized
data.content: Cells of the cardiac conduction system are electrically excitable, charge difference is lost and the inner membrane charge shifts toward positive

data.title: Diastole
data.content: Relaxation in cardiac cycle

data.title: Diastolic pressure
data.content: The pressure when the heart relaxes and fills with blood, the second number reported on a blood pressure reading

data.title: Electrocardiogram (ECG, EKG)
data.content: A graph of the heart’s electrical activity

data.title: Heart rate (HR)
data.content: the number of times a heart beats in given amount of time, generally a minute

data.title: Heart sounds
data.content: Produced by the closing of heart valves, which results in a temporary disturbance in blood flow

data.title: Hypertension
data.content: A  blood pressure of 140/90 or greater

data.title: Hypotension
data.content: Blood pressure is 90/60 or lower

data.title: Interval rate
data.content: The time between the peaks on a ECG

data.title: Isovolumetric contraction
data.content: A brief time when all four heart valves are closed and the volume of blood in the ventricles remains steady

data.title: Isovolumetric relaxation
data.content: Interval between aortic valve closure and mitral valve opening

data.title: Mean arterial pressure (MAP)
data.content: The pressure that forces arterial blood to the capillary beds

data.title: Myocardial infarction (MI)
data.content: A heart attack, when blood flow to part of the heart is interrupted

data.title: Myocardium
data.content: Muscular walls of the heart

data.title: P wave
data.content: In an ECG, corresponds to depolarization of the atria

data.title: Palpation
data.content: Feeling with the fingertips

data.title: PR interval
data.content: In an ECG, the time from the onset of the P wave to the onset of the Q wave, from the arrival of the depolarization signal at the atria to its arrival at the ventricles

data.title: PR segment
data.content: In an ECG, starts at the end of the P wave and ends at the beginning of the Q wave

data.title: Prehypertension
data.content: At high risk of developing hypertension

data.title: Pulmonary valve
data.content: A valve between the pulmonary artery and the right ventricle of the heart, prevents blood from flowing back into the right ventricle

data.title: Pulse
data.content: Pressure waves detected by palpation

data.title: Pulse points
data.content: Pressure waves in certain arteries close to the body’s surface can be detected via palpation

data.title: Pulse pressure (PP)
data.content: The difference between systolic pressure and diastolic pressure

data.title: Purkinje fibers
data.content: Relay electrical signals from bundle branches throughout the walls of the ventricles

data.title: Q wave
data.content: In an ECG, represents depolarization of the interventricular septum

data.title: QRS complex
data.content: In an ECG, indicates depolarization of the ventricles

data.title: QT interval
data.content: In an ECG, the time from the start of the Q wave to the end of the T wave, from the arrival of ventricular depolarization to repolarization of the ventricles

data.title: R wave
data.content: In an ECG, is the largest wave of an ECG and depicts depolarization of the ventricles

data.title: Repolarization
data.content: Restoration of the difference in charge between the inside and outside of the plasma membrane of a cell following depolarization

data.title: S wave
data.content: In an ECG, generated by depolarization of the Purkinje fibers, occurring late in ventricular depolarization

data.title: Sinoatrial (SA) node
data.content: Located in the superior and posterior region of the right atrium, the pacemaker of the heart, generates the electrical signal for contraction and sets the basic heart rate

data.title: Sphygmomanometer
data.content: Blood pressure cuff, used to measure arterial blood pressure

data.title: ST segment
data.content: In an ECG, the time from the end of the QRS complex to the start of the T wave, during which the ventricles are completely depolarized

data.title: Stroke volume (SV)
data.content: The volume of blood ejected from a single ventricle, typically the left ventricle, with each contraction

data.title: Systole
data.content: Contraction in cardiac cycle

data.title: Systolic pressure
data.content: The pressure caused by the heart contracting and pushing out blood, the top number on a blood pressure reading

data.title: T wave
data.content: In an ECG, indicates the repolarization of the ventricles

data.title: Tachycardia
data.content: A pulse over 100 bpm

data.title: Tricuspid valve
data.content: Consists of three thin flaps, sits between the heart's two right chambers

data.title: Venae cavae
data.content: A large vein carrying deoxygenated blood to the heart

data.title: Ventricles
data.content: The lower two chambers of the heart, “pumping chambers”, forcefully eject blood from the heart
